taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Greek cheima, winter, and philia, love, alluding to evergreen habit]

bio:treatment.discussion: Ethnobotanical studies have documented a wide variety of drug and food uses of Chimaphila among more than two dozen tribes of Native Americans (D. E. Moerman 1998; K. Sheth et al. 1967).

references.reference: Standley, L. A., S. S.-H. Kim, and I. M. Hjersted. 1988. Reproductive biology of two sympatric species of Chimaphila. Rhodora 90: 233–244.
Takahashi, Hiroshi. 1986b. Pollen polyads and their variation in Chimaphila (Pyrolaceae). Grana 25: 161–169.

key_statement.description: Inflorescence bracts broadly ovate to broadly obovate; inflorescences 1–3-flowered; calyx lobes (3–)5–6.5 mm; stigmas 1.6–2.2(–2.8) mm wide
Inflorescence bracts acicular to linear-lanceolate; inflorescences (1–)2–7-flowered; calyx lobes 1–4.1 mm; stigmas 2–4 mm wide.
Leaf blades maculate; dilated basal portions of filaments densely villous
Leaf blades not maculate; dilated basal portions of filaments ciliate
